segment.source: Marble Maze application structure
segment.target: Marble Maze application structure

segment.source: The structure of a DirectX Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app differs from that of a traditional desktop application.
segment.target: The structure of a DirectX Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app differs from that of a traditional desktop application.

segment.source: Marble Maze application structure
segment.target: Marble Maze application structure

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: The structure of a DirectX Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app differs from that of a traditional desktop application.
segment.target: The structure of a DirectX Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app differs from that of a traditional desktop application.

segment.source: Instead of working with handle types such as HWND and functions such as CreateWindow, the Windows Runtime provides interfaces such as Windows::UI::Core::ICoreWindow so that you can develop UWP apps in a more modern, object-oriented manner.
segment.target: Instead of working with handle types such as HWND and functions such as CreateWindow, the Windows Runtime provides interfaces such as Windows::UI::Core::ICoreWindow so that you can develop UWP apps in a more modern, object-oriented manner.

segment.source: This section of the documentation shows how the Marble Maze application code is structured.
segment.target: This section of the documentation shows how the Marble Maze application code is structured.

segment.source: Note The sample code that corresponds to this document is found in the DirectX Marble Maze game sample.
segment.target: Note The sample code that corresponds to this document is found in the DirectX Marble Maze game sample.

segment.source: Here are some of the key points that this document discusses for when you structure your game code:
segment.target: Here are some of the key points that this document discusses for when you structure your game code:

segment.source: In the initialization phase, set up runtime and library components that your game uses.
segment.target: In the initialization phase, set up runtime and library components that your game uses.

segment.source: Also load game-specific resources.
segment.target: Also load game-specific resources.

segment.source: UWP apps must start processing events within 5 seconds of launch.
segment.target: UWP apps must start processing events within 5 seconds of launch.

segment.source: Therefore, load only essential resources when you load your app.
segment.target: Therefore, load only essential resources when you load your app.

segment.source: Games should load large resources in the background and display a progress screen.
segment.target: Games should load large resources in the background and display a progress screen.

segment.source: In the game loop, respond to Windows events, read user input, update scene objects, and render the scene.
segment.target: In the game loop, respond to Windows events, read user input, update scene objects, and render the scene.

segment.source: Use event handlers to respond to window events.
segment.target: Use event handlers to respond to window events.

segment.source: (These replace the window messages from desktop Windows applications.)
segment.target: (These replace the window messages from desktop Windows applications.)

segment.source: Use a state machine to control the flow and order of the game logic.
segment.target: Use a state machine to control the flow and order of the game logic.

segment.source: File organization
segment.target: File organization

segment.source: Some of the components in Marble Maze can be reused with any game with little or no modification.
segment.target: Some of the components in Marble Maze can be reused with any game with little or no modification.

segment.source: For your own game, you can adapt the organization and ideas that these files provide.
segment.target: For your own game, you can adapt the organization and ideas that these files provide.

segment.source: The following table briefly describes the important source code files.
segment.target: The following table briefly describes the important source code files.

segment.source: Files
segment.target: Files

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Audio.h, Audio.cpp
segment.target: Audio.h, Audio.cpp

segment.source: Defines the Audio class, which manages audio resources.
segment.target: Defines the Audio class, which manages audio resources.

segment.source: BasicLoader.h, BasicLoader.cpp
segment.target: BasicLoader.h, BasicLoader.cpp

segment.source: Defines the BasicLoader class, which provides utility methods that help you load textures, meshes, and shaders.
segment.target: Defines the BasicLoader class, which provides utility methods that help you load textures, meshes, and shaders.

segment.source: BasicMath.h
segment.target: BasicMath.h

segment.source: Defines structures and functions that help you work with vector and matrix data and computations.
segment.target: Defines structures and functions that help you work with vector and matrix data and computations.

segment.source: Many of these functions are compatible with HLSL shader types.
segment.target: Many of these functions are compatible with HLSL shader types.

segment.source: BasicReaderWriter.h, BasicReaderWriter.cpp
segment.target: BasicReaderWriter.h, BasicReaderWriter.cpp

segment.source: Defines the BasicReaderWriter class, which uses the Windows Runtime to read and write file data in a UWP app.
segment.target: Defines the BasicReaderWriter class, which uses the Windows Runtime to read and write file data in a UWP app.

segment.source: BasicShapes.h, BasicShapes.cpp
segment.target: BasicShapes.h, BasicShapes.cpp

segment.source: Defines the BasicShapes class, which provides utility methods for creating basic shapes such as cubes and spheres.
segment.target: Defines the BasicShapes class, which provides utility methods for creating basic shapes such as cubes and spheres.

segment.source: (These files are not used by the Marble Maze implementation).
segment.target: (These files are not used by the Marble Maze implementation).

segment.source: BasicTimer.h, BasicTimer.cpp
segment.target: BasicTimer.h, BasicTimer.cpp

segment.source: Defines the BasicTimer class, which provides an easy way to get total and elapsed times.
segment.target: Defines the BasicTimer class, which provides an easy way to get total and elapsed times.

segment.source: Camera.h, Camera.cpp
segment.target: Camera.h, Camera.cpp

segment.source: Defines the Camera class, which provides the position and orientation of a camera.
segment.target: Defines the Camera class, which provides the position and orientation of a camera.

segment.source: Collision.h, Collision.cpp
segment.target: Collision.h, Collision.cpp

segment.source: Manages collision info between the marble and other objects, such as the maze.
segment.target: Manages collision info between the marble and other objects, such as the maze.

segment.source: DDSTextureLoader.h, DDSTextureLoader.cpp
segment.target: DDSTextureLoader.h, DDSTextureLoader.cpp

segment.source: Defines the CreateDDSTextureFromMemory function, which loads textures that are in .dds format from a memory buffer.
segment.target: Defines the CreateDDSTextureFromMemory function, which loads textures that are in .dds format from a memory buffer.

segment.source: DirectXApp.h, DirectXApp.cpp
segment.target: DirectXApp.h, DirectXApp.cpp

segment.source: Defines the DirectXApp and DirectXAppSource classes, which encapsulate the view (window, thread, and events) of the app.
segment.target: Defines the DirectXApp and DirectXAppSource classes, which encapsulate the view (window, thread, and events) of the app.

segment.source: DirectXBase.h, DirectXBase.cpp
segment.target: DirectXBase.h, DirectXBase.cpp

segment.source: Defines the DirectXBase class, which provides infrastructure that is common to many DirectX UWP apps.
segment.target: Defines the DirectXBase class, which provides infrastructure that is common to many DirectX UWP apps.

segment.source: DirectXSample.h
segment.target: DirectXSample.h

segment.source: Defines utility functions that can be used by DirectX UWP apps.
segment.target: Defines utility functions that can be used by DirectX UWP apps.

segment.source: LoadScreen.h, LoadScreen.cpp
segment.target: LoadScreen.h, LoadScreen.cpp

segment.source: Defines the LoadScreen class, which displays a loading screen during app initialization.
segment.target: Defines the LoadScreen class, which displays a loading screen during app initialization.

segment.source: MarbleMaze.h, MarbleMaze.cpp
segment.target: MarbleMaze.h, MarbleMaze.cpp

segment.source: Defines the MarbleMaze class, which manages game-specific resources and defines much of the game logic.
segment.target: Defines the MarbleMaze class, which manages game-specific resources and defines much of the game logic.

segment.source: MediaStreamer.h, MediaStreamer.cpp
segment.target: MediaStreamer.h, MediaStreamer.cpp

segment.source: Defines the MediaStreamer class, which uses Media Foundation to help the game manage audio resources.
segment.target: Defines the MediaStreamer class, which uses Media Foundation to help the game manage audio resources.

segment.source: PersistentState.h, PersistentState.cpp
segment.target: PersistentState.h, PersistentState.cpp

segment.source: Defines the PersistentState class, which reads and writes primitive data types from and to a backing store.
segment.target: Defines the PersistentState class, which reads and writes primitive data types from and to a backing store.

segment.source: Physics.h, Physics.cpp
segment.target: Physics.h, Physics.cpp

segment.source: Defines the Physics class, which implements the physics simulation between the marble and the maze.
segment.target: Defines the Physics class, which implements the physics simulation between the marble and the maze.

segment.source: Primitives.h
segment.target: Primitives.h

segment.source: Defines geometric types that are used by the game.
segment.target: Defines geometric types that are used by the game.

segment.source: SampleOverlay.h, SampleOverlay.cpp
segment.target: SampleOverlay.h, SampleOverlay.cpp

segment.source: Defines the SampleOverlay class, which provides common 2-D and user-interface data and operations.
segment.target: Defines the SampleOverlay class, which provides common 2-D and user-interface data and operations.

segment.source: SDKMesh.h, SDKMesh.cpp
segment.target: SDKMesh.h, SDKMesh.cpp

segment.source: Defines the SDKMesh class, which loads and renders meshes that are in SDK Mesh (.sdkmesh) format.
segment.target: Defines the SDKMesh class, which loads and renders meshes that are in SDK Mesh (.sdkmesh) format.

segment.source: UserInterface.h, UserInterface.cpp
segment.target: UserInterface.h, UserInterface.cpp

segment.source: Defines functionality that's related to the user interface, such as the menu system and the high score table.
segment.target: Defines functionality that's related to the user interface, such as the menu system and the high score table.

segment.source: Design-time versus run-time resource formats
segment.target: Design-time versus run-time resource formats

segment.source: When you can, use run-time formats instead of design-time formats to more efficiently load game resources.
segment.target: When you can, use run-time formats instead of design-time formats to more efficiently load game resources.

segment.source: A design-time format is the format you use when you design your resource.
segment.target: A design-time format is the format you use when you design your resource.

segment.source: Typically, 3-D designers work with design-time formats.
segment.target: Typically, 3-D designers work with design-time formats.

segment.source: Some design-time formats are also text-based so that you can modify them in any text-based editor.
segment.target: Some design-time formats are also text-based so that you can modify them in any text-based editor.

segment.source: Design-time formats can be verbose and contain more information than your game requires.
segment.target: Design-time formats can be verbose and contain more information than your game requires.

segment.source: A run-time format is the binary format that is read by your game.
segment.target: A run-time format is the binary format that is read by your game.

segment.source: Run-time formats are typically more compact and more efficient to load than the corresponding design-time formats.
segment.target: Run-time formats are typically more compact and more efficient to load than the corresponding design-time formats.

segment.source: This is why the majority of games use run-time assets at run time.
segment.target: This is why the majority of games use run-time assets at run time.

segment.source: Although your game can directly read a design-time format, there are several benefits to using a separate run-time format.
segment.target: Although your game can directly read a design-time format, there are several benefits to using a separate run-time format.

segment.source: Because run-time formats are often more compact, they require less disk space and require less time to transfer over a network.
segment.target: Because run-time formats are often more compact, they require less disk space and require less time to transfer over a network.

segment.source: Also, run-time formats are often represented as memory-mapped data structures.
segment.target: Also, run-time formats are often represented as memory-mapped data structures.

segment.source: Therefore, they can be loaded into memory much faster than, for example, an XML-based text file.
segment.target: Therefore, they can be loaded into memory much faster than, for example, an XML-based text file.

segment.source: Finally, because separate run-time formats are typically binary-encoded, they are more difficult for the end-user to modify.
segment.target: Finally, because separate run-time formats are typically binary-encoded, they are more difficult for the end-user to modify.

segment.source: HLSL shaders are one example of resources that use different design-time and run-time formats.
segment.target: HLSL shaders are one example of resources that use different design-time and run-time formats.

segment.source: Marble Maze uses .hlsl as the design-time format, and .cso as the run-time format.
segment.target: Marble Maze uses .hlsl as the design-time format, and .cso as the run-time format.

segment.source: A .hlsl file holds source code for the shader; a .cso file holds the corresponding shader byte code.
segment.target: A .hlsl file holds source code for the shader; a .cso file holds the corresponding shader byte code.

segment.source: When you convert .hlsl files offline and provide .cso files with your game, you avoid the need to convert HLSL source files to byte code when your game loads.
segment.target: When you convert .hlsl files offline and provide .cso files with your game, you avoid the need to convert HLSL source files to byte code when your game loads.

segment.source: For instructional reasons, the Marble Maze project includes both the design-time format and the run-time format for many resources, but you only have to maintain the design-time formats in the source project for your own game because you can convert them to run-time formats when you need them.
segment.target: For instructional reasons, the Marble Maze project includes both the design-time format and the run-time format for many resources, but you only have to maintain the design-time formats in the source project for your own game because you can convert them to run-time formats when you need them.

segment.source: This documentation shows how to convert the design-time formats to the run-time formats.
segment.target: This documentation shows how to convert the design-time formats to the run-time formats.

segment.source: Application life cycle
segment.target: Application life cycle

segment.source: Marble Maze follows the life cycle of a typical UWP app.
segment.target: Marble Maze follows the life cycle of a typical UWP app.

segment.source: For more info about the life cycle of a UWP app, see App lifecycle.
segment.target: For more info about the life cycle of a UWP app, see App lifecycle.

segment.source: When a UWP game initializes, it typically initializes runtime components such as Direct3D, Direct2D, and any input, audio, or physics libraries that it uses.
segment.target: When a UWP game initializes, it typically initializes runtime components such as Direct3D, Direct2D, and any input, audio, or physics libraries that it uses.

segment.source: It also loads game-specific resources that are required before the game begins.
segment.target: It also loads game-specific resources that are required before the game begins.

segment.source: This initialization occurs one time during a game session.
segment.target: This initialization occurs one time during a game session.

segment.source: After initialization, games typically run the game loop.
segment.target: After initialization, games typically run the game loop.

segment.source: In this loop, games typically perform four actions: process Windows events, collect input, update scene objects, and render the scene.
segment.target: In this loop, games typically perform four actions: process Windows events, collect input, update scene objects, and render the scene.

segment.source: When the game updates the scene, it can apply the current input state to the scene objects and simulate physical events, such as object collisions.
segment.target: When the game updates the scene, it can apply the current input state to the scene objects and simulate physical events, such as object collisions.

segment.source: The game can also perform other activities such as playing sound effects or sending data over the network.
segment.target: The game can also perform other activities such as playing sound effects or sending data over the network.

segment.source: When the game renders the scene, it captures the current state of the scene and draws it to the display device.
segment.target: When the game renders the scene, it captures the current state of the scene and draws it to the display device.

segment.source: The following sections describe these activities in greater detail.
segment.target: The following sections describe these activities in greater detail.

segment.source: Adding to the template
segment.target: Adding to the template

segment.source: The DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template creates a core window that you can render to with Direct3D.
segment.target: The DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template creates a core window that you can render to with Direct3D.

segment.source: The template also includes the DeviceResources class that creates all of the Direct3D device resources needed for rendering 3D content in a UWP app.
segment.target: The template also includes the DeviceResources class that creates all of the Direct3D device resources needed for rendering 3D content in a UWP app.

segment.source: The AppMain class creates the MarbleMaze class object, starts the loading of resources, loops to update the timer, and calls the MarbleMaze render method each frame.
segment.target: The AppMain class creates the MarbleMaze class object, starts the loading of resources, loops to update the timer, and calls the MarbleMaze render method each frame.

segment.source: The CreateWindowSizeDependentResources, Update, and Render methods for this class call the corresponding methods in the MarbleMaze class.
segment.target: The CreateWindowSizeDependentResources, Update, and Render methods for this class call the corresponding methods in the MarbleMaze class.

segment.source: The following example shows where the AppMain constructor creates the MarbleMaze class object.
segment.target: The following example shows where the AppMain constructor creates the MarbleMaze class object.

segment.source: The device resources class is passed to the class so it can use the Direct3D objects for rendering.
segment.target: The device resources class is passed to the class so it can use the Direct3D objects for rendering.

segment.source: The AppMain class also starts loading the deferred resources for the game.
segment.target: The AppMain class also starts loading the deferred resources for the game.

segment.source: See the next section for more detail.
segment.target: See the next section for more detail.

segment.source: The DirectXPage constructor sets up the event handlers, creates the DeviceResources class, and creates the AppMain class.
segment.target: The DirectXPage constructor sets up the event handlers, creates the DeviceResources class, and creates the AppMain class.

segment.source: When the handlers for these events are called, they pass the input to the MarbleMaze class.
segment.target: When the handlers for these events are called, they pass the input to the MarbleMaze class.

segment.source: Loading game assets in the background
segment.target: Loading game assets in the background

segment.source: To ensure that your game can respond to window events within 5 seconds after it is launched, we recommend that you load your game assets asynchronously, or in the background.
segment.target: To ensure that your game can respond to window events within 5 seconds after it is launched, we recommend that you load your game assets asynchronously, or in the background.

segment.source: As assets load in the background, your game can respond to window events.
segment.target: As assets load in the background, your game can respond to window events.

segment.source: Note You can also display the main menu when it is ready, and allow the remaining assets to continue loading in the background.
segment.target: Note You can also display the main menu when it is ready, and allow the remaining assets to continue loading in the background.

segment.source: If the user selects an option from the menu before all resources are loaded, you can indicate that scene resources are continuing to load by displaying a progress bar, for example.
segment.target: If the user selects an option from the menu before all resources are loaded, you can indicate that scene resources are continuing to load by displaying a progress bar, for example.

segment.source: Even if your game contains relatively few game assets, it is good practice to load them asynchronously for two reasons.
segment.target: Even if your game contains relatively few game assets, it is good practice to load them asynchronously for two reasons.

segment.source: One reason is that it is difficult to guarantee that all of your resources will load quickly on all devices and all configurations.
segment.target: One reason is that it is difficult to guarantee that all of your resources will load quickly on all devices and all configurations.

segment.source: Also, by incorporating asynchronous loading early, your code is ready to scale as you add functionality.
segment.target: Also, by incorporating asynchronous loading early, your code is ready to scale as you add functionality.

segment.source: Asynchronous asset loading begins with the AppMain::Load method.
segment.target: Asynchronous asset loading begins with the AppMain::Load method.

segment.source: This method uses the task Class (Concurrency Runtime) class to load game assets in the background.
segment.target: This method uses the task Class (Concurrency Runtime) class to load game assets in the background.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze class defines the m\_deferredResourcesReady flag to indicate that asynchronous loading is complete.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze class defines the m\_deferredResourcesReady flag to indicate that asynchronous loading is complete.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze::LoadDeferredResources method loads the game resources and then sets this flag.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze::LoadDeferredResources method loads the game resources and then sets this flag.

segment.source: The update (MarbleMaze::Update) and render (MarbleMaze::Render) phases of the app check this flag.
segment.target: The update (MarbleMaze::Update) and render (MarbleMaze::Render) phases of the app check this flag.

segment.source: When this flag is set, the game continues as normal.
segment.target: When this flag is set, the game continues as normal.

segment.source: If the flag is not yet set, the game shows the loading screen.
segment.target: If the flag is not yet set, the game shows the loading screen.

segment.source: For more information about asynchronous programming for UWP apps, see Asynchronous programming in C++.
segment.target: For more information about asynchronous programming for UWP apps, see Asynchronous programming in C++.

segment.source: Tip If you’re writing game code that is part of a Windows Runtime C++ Library (in other words, a DLL), consider whether to read Creating Asynchronous Operations in C++ for Windows Store Apps to learn how to create asynchronous operations that can be consumed by apps and other libraries.
segment.target: Tip If you’re writing game code that is part of a Windows Runtime C++ Library (in other words, a DLL), consider whether to read Creating Asynchronous Operations in C++ for Windows Store Apps to learn how to create asynchronous operations that can be consumed by apps and other libraries.

segment.source: The game loop
segment.target: The game loop

segment.source: The DirectPage::OnRendering method runs the main game loop.
segment.target: The DirectPage::OnRendering method runs the main game loop.

segment.source: This method is called every frame.
segment.target: This method is called every frame.

segment.source: To help separate view and window code from game-specific code, we implemented the DirectXApp::Run method to forward update and render calls to the MarbleMaze object.
segment.target: To help separate view and window code from game-specific code, we implemented the DirectXApp::Run method to forward update and render calls to the MarbleMaze object.

segment.source: The DirectPage::OnRendering method also defines the game timer, which is used for animation and physics simulation.
segment.target: The DirectPage::OnRendering method also defines the game timer, which is used for animation and physics simulation.

segment.source: The following example shows the DirectPage::OnRendering method, which includes the main game loop.
segment.target: The following example shows the DirectPage::OnRendering method, which includes the main game loop.

segment.source: The game loop updates the total time and frame time variables, and then updates and renders the scene.
segment.target: The game loop updates the total time and frame time variables, and then updates and renders the scene.

segment.source: This also makes sure that content is only rendered when the window is visible.
segment.target: This also makes sure that content is only rendered when the window is visible.

segment.source: The state machine
segment.target: The state machine

segment.source: Games typically contain a state machine (also known as a finite state machine, or FSM) to control the flow and order of the game logic.
segment.target: Games typically contain a state machine (also known as a finite state machine, or FSM) to control the flow and order of the game logic.

segment.source: A state machine contains a given number of states and the ability to transition among them.
segment.target: A state machine contains a given number of states and the ability to transition among them.

segment.source: A state machine typically starts from an initial state, transitions to one or more intermediate states, and possibly ends at a terminal state.
segment.target: A state machine typically starts from an initial state, transitions to one or more intermediate states, and possibly ends at a terminal state.

segment.source: A game loop often uses a state machine so that it can perform the logic that is specific to the current game state.
segment.target: A game loop often uses a state machine so that it can perform the logic that is specific to the current game state.

segment.source: Marble Maze defines the GameState enumeration, which defines each possible state of the game.
segment.target: Marble Maze defines the GameState enumeration, which defines each possible state of the game.

segment.source: The MainMenu state, for example, defines that the main menu appears, and that the game is not active.
segment.target: The MainMenu state, for example, defines that the main menu appears, and that the game is not active.

segment.source: Conversely, the InGameActive state defines that the game is active, and that the menu does not appear.
segment.target: Conversely, the InGameActive state defines that the game is active, and that the menu does not appear.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze class defines the m\_gameState member variable to hold the active game state.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze class defines the m\_gameState member variable to hold the active game state.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze::Update and MarbleMaze::Render methods use the switch statement to perform logic for the current state.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze::Update and MarbleMaze::Render methods use the switch statement to perform logic for the current state.

segment.source: The following example shows what this switch statement might look like for the MarbleMaze::Update method (details are removed to illustrate the structure).
segment.target: The following example shows what this switch statement might look like for the MarbleMaze::Update method (details are removed to illustrate the structure).

segment.source: When game logic or rendering depends on a specific game state, we emphasize it in this documentation.
segment.target: When game logic or rendering depends on a specific game state, we emphasize it in this documentation.

segment.source: Handling app and window events
segment.target: Handling app and window events

segment.source: The Windows Runtime provides an object-oriented event-handling system so that you can more easily manage Windows messages.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime provides an object-oriented event-handling system so that you can more easily manage Windows messages.

segment.source: To consume an event in an application, you must provide an event handler, or event-handling method, that responds to the event.
segment.target: To consume an event in an application, you must provide an event handler, or event-handling method, that responds to the event.

segment.source: You must also register the event handler with the event source.
segment.target: You must also register the event handler with the event source.

segment.source: This process is often referred to as event wiring.
segment.target: This process is often referred to as event wiring.

segment.source: Supporting suspend, resume, and restart
segment.target: Supporting suspend, resume, and restart

segment.source: Marble Maze is suspended when the user switches away from it or when Windows enters a low power state.
segment.target: Marble Maze is suspended when the user switches away from it or when Windows enters a low power state.

segment.source: The game is resumed when the user moves it to the foreground or when Windows comes out of a low power state.
segment.target: The game is resumed when the user moves it to the foreground or when Windows comes out of a low power state.

segment.source: Generally, you don't close apps.
segment.target: Generally, you don't close apps.

segment.source: Windows can terminate the app when it's in the suspended state and Windows requires the resources, such as memory, that the app is using.
segment.target: Windows can terminate the app when it's in the suspended state and Windows requires the resources, such as memory, that the app is using.

segment.source: Windows notifies an app when it is about to be suspended or resumed, but it doesn't notify the app when it's about to be terminated.
segment.target: Windows notifies an app when it is about to be suspended or resumed, but it doesn't notify the app when it's about to be terminated.

segment.source: Therefore, your app must be able to save—at the point when Windows notifies your app that it is about to be suspended—any data that would be required to restore the current user state when the app is restarted.
segment.target: Therefore, your app must be able to save—at the point when Windows notifies your app that it is about to be suspended—any data that would be required to restore the current user state when the app is restarted.

segment.source: If your app has significant user state that is expensive to save, you may also need to save state regularly, even before your app receives the suspend notification.
segment.target: If your app has significant user state that is expensive to save, you may also need to save state regularly, even before your app receives the suspend notification.

segment.source: Marble Maze responds to suspend and resume notifications for two reasons:
segment.target: Marble Maze responds to suspend and resume notifications for two reasons:

segment.source: When the app is suspended, the game saves the current game state and pauses audio playback.
segment.target: When the app is suspended, the game saves the current game state and pauses audio playback.

segment.source: When the app is resumed, the game resumes audio playback.
segment.target: When the app is resumed, the game resumes audio playback.

segment.source: When the app is closed and later restarted, the game resumes from its previous state.
segment.target: When the app is closed and later restarted, the game resumes from its previous state.

segment.source: Marble Maze performs the following tasks to support suspend and resume:
segment.target: Marble Maze performs the following tasks to support suspend and resume:

segment.source: It saves its state to persistent storage at key points in the game, such as when the user reaches a checkpoint.
segment.target: It saves its state to persistent storage at key points in the game, such as when the user reaches a checkpoint.

segment.source: It responds to suspend notifications by saving its state to persistent storage.
segment.target: It responds to suspend notifications by saving its state to persistent storage.

segment.source: It responds to resume notifications by loading its state from persistent storage.
segment.target: It responds to resume notifications by loading its state from persistent storage.

segment.source: It also loads the previous state during startup.
segment.target: It also loads the previous state during startup.

segment.source: To support suspend and resume, Marble Maze defines the PersistentState class.
segment.target: To support suspend and resume, Marble Maze defines the PersistentState class.

segment.source: (See PersistentState.h and PersistentState.cpp).
segment.target: (See PersistentState.h and PersistentState.cpp).

segment.source: This class uses the Windows::Foundation::Collections::IPropertySet interface to read and write properties.
segment.target: This class uses the Windows::Foundation::Collections::IPropertySet interface to read and write properties.

segment.source: The PersistentState class provides methods that read and write primitive data types (such as bool, int, float, XMFLOAT3, and Platform::String), from and to a backing store.
segment.target: The PersistentState class provides methods that read and write primitive data types (such as bool, int, float, XMFLOAT3, and Platform::String), from and to a backing store.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze class holds a PersistentState object.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze class holds a PersistentState object.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze constructor initializes this object and provides the local application data store as the backing data store.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze constructor initializes this object and provides the local application data store as the backing data store.

segment.source: Marble Maze saves its state when the marble passes over a checkpoint or the goal (in the MarbleMaze::Update method), and when the window loses focus (in the MarbleMaze::OnFocusChange method).
segment.target: Marble Maze saves its state when the marble passes over a checkpoint or the goal (in the MarbleMaze::Update method), and when the window loses focus (in the MarbleMaze::OnFocusChange method).

segment.source: If your game holds a large amount of state data, we recommend that you occasionally save state to persistent storage in a similar manner because you only have a few seconds to respond to the suspend notification.
segment.target: If your game holds a large amount of state data, we recommend that you occasionally save state to persistent storage in a similar manner because you only have a few seconds to respond to the suspend notification.

segment.source: Therefore, when your app receives a suspend notification, it only has to save the state data that has changed.
segment.target: Therefore, when your app receives a suspend notification, it only has to save the state data that has changed.

segment.source: To respond to suspend and resume notifications, the DirectXPage class defines the SaveInternalState and LoadInternalState methods that are called on suspend and resume.
segment.target: To respond to suspend and resume notifications, the DirectXPage class defines the SaveInternalState and LoadInternalState methods that are called on suspend and resume.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze::OnSuspending method handles the suspend event and the MarbleMaze::OnResuming method handles the resume event.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze::OnSuspending method handles the suspend event and the MarbleMaze::OnResuming method handles the resume event.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze::OnSuspending method saves game state and suspends audio.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze::OnSuspending method saves game state and suspends audio.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze::SaveState method saves game state values such as the current position and velocity of the marble, the most recent checkpoint, and the high-score table.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze::SaveState method saves game state values such as the current position and velocity of the marble, the most recent checkpoint, and the high-score table.

segment.source: When the game resumes, it only has to resume audio.
segment.target: When the game resumes, it only has to resume audio.

segment.source: It doesn't have to load state from persistent storage because the state is already loaded in memory.
segment.target: It doesn't have to load state from persistent storage because the state is already loaded in memory.

segment.source: How the game suspends and resumes audio is explained in the document Adding audio to the Marble Maze sample.
segment.target: How the game suspends and resumes audio is explained in the document Adding audio to the Marble Maze sample.

segment.source: To support restart, the MarbleMaze::Initialize method, which is called during startup, calls the MarbleMaze::LoadState method.
segment.target: To support restart, the MarbleMaze::Initialize method, which is called during startup, calls the MarbleMaze::LoadState method.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze::LoadState method reads and applies the state to the game objects.
segment.target: The MarbleMaze::LoadState method reads and applies the state to the game objects.

segment.source: This method also sets the current game state to paused if the game was paused or active when it was suspended.
segment.target: This method also sets the current game state to paused if the game was paused or active when it was suspended.

segment.source: We pause the game so that the user is not surprised by unexpected activity.
segment.target: We pause the game so that the user is not surprised by unexpected activity.

segment.source: It also moves to the main menu if the game was not in a gameplay state when it was suspended.
segment.target: It also moves to the main menu if the game was not in a gameplay state when it was suspended.

segment.source: Important Marble Maze doesn't distinguish between cold starting—that is, starting for the first time without a prior suspend event—and resuming from a suspended state.
segment.target: Important Marble Maze doesn't distinguish between cold starting—that is, starting for the first time without a prior suspend event—and resuming from a suspended state.

segment.source: This is recommended design for all UWP apps.
segment.target: This is recommended design for all UWP apps.

segment.source: For more examples that demonstrate how to store and retrieve settings and files from the local application data store, see Quickstart: Local application data.
segment.target: For more examples that demonstrate how to store and retrieve settings and files from the local application data store, see Quickstart: Local application data.

segment.source: For more info about application data, see Store and retrieve settings and other app data.
segment.target: For more info about application data, see Store and retrieve settings and other app data.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: Read Adding visual content to the Marble Maze sample for information about some of the key practices to keep in mind when you work with visual resources.
segment.target: Read Adding visual content to the Marble Maze sample for information about some of the key practices to keep in mind when you work with visual resources.
